Yes, you can continue to use ClockKit complications with a SwiftUI app. The setup is the same as previously, however, Xcode no longer creates a ClockKit complication for you when you create a new app.

You can set it up manually by creating a class that conforms to `CLKComplicationDataSource` and then setting that as the value for the `CLKComplicationsPrincipalClass` key in your app's Info.plist.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Background timeline reloads are usually opportunistic, so they might not run at exactly the time you've requested. I'd recommend scheduling some reloads in advance of your timeline ending to ensure it reloads in time. It's also possible your reload is running slightly ahead of the time you've scheduled it, and your timeline always fills the current day instead of filling 24 hours in the future from the time that its run, so it could be filling the timeline with entries of the day that's about to end instead of the upcoming day. You could switch your logic to always fill 24 hours from the current date, instead of 24 hours starting from midnight of the current day.

Certainly asking `WidgetCenter` for a reload from a notification is one way.  However, note that this will still ask for an opportunistic update when the system finds a good time to update your widget.  Your request may be honored right away, or it may be honored slightly later.

In general, a set periodic update is a good policy here - to update at a regular interval throughout the day.  Something like a timeline reload policy of:  `.afterDate` for a specific interval (15-20 minutes?)

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Calling reload from `applicationWillTerminate` can work if your app is foreground at the point the user was terminating it.

However, it won't work if the app was backgrounded and not currently foreground at the point of termination (ie. the system terminates it for memory reclaimation, or the user terminates it from the App Switcher).
